importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of Sarkozy's entry into prison marks a historic moment as the first former French president to be imprisoned, raising national and international attention on judicial accountability and political integrity.
Sarkozy's presidency began in 2007, setting the context for the alleged campaign financing scandal that later led to his imprisonment.

France's highest administrative court will deliver its verdict on Sarkozy's appeal in the Bygmalion affair, potentially overturning or confirming his conviction, signaling a pivotal moment in judicial review of political misconduct.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe of Sarkozy's presidency (2007–2012) is central to the campaign finance allegations, as the illegal funding is alleged to have occurred during his presidential campaign.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's first ex-president to go to jail, is serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 campaign with money from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, not for personally receiving Libyan funds, but for enabling secret campaign financing.
The case is part of a broader scandal known as the 'Bygmalion affair', involving illicit campaign financing via a Franco-Lebanese intermediary, Ziad Tiakeddine.
Sarkozy has appealed the conviction and claims innocence, asserting that the judicial decision reflects political revenge rather than truth.
He is currently detained in La Santé prison's isolation wing, with strict conditions including solitary confinement, limited contact, and restricted daily activities.
Despite the harsh conditions, Sarkozy maintains dignity and has requested no special treatment, citing the need to uphold his integrity and the rule of law.
President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin have publicly expressed support, acknowledging the human and political implications of the situation.
Sarkozy continues to be a symbol of the tension between political accountability and political immunity, particularly in post-presidential judicial scrutiny.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, the first former president of France to be imprisoned, has begun serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 presidential campaign with money from Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. Though he denies wrongdoing and claims innocence, he was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who facilitated secret meetings with Libyan officials through intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. Sarkozy is currently held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison in Paris, where conditions are harsh and contact with other inmates is strictly limited. He has appealed the conviction and is awaiting a final verdict from France’s highest administrative court on the Bygmalion affair. The case has drawn significant public attention, with President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin expressing support, emphasizing the gravity of the situation and the human cost of political accountability.
title: Sarkozy enters jail over campaign financing - France's first ex-president behind bars
